lessons.title: Sport and fitness value chain map
lessons.content:
# Sport and fitness value chain map

**Objective:** Build a buyer-reality map for a sport or fitness offer by identifying payers, economic buyers, technical buyers, champions, users, blockers, and governance functions.

## Key concepts

*   buying committee roles (payer, economic buyer, technical buyer, users)
*   champion versus coach versus sponsor
*   procurement and legal as process owners
*   seasonality and operational constraints in sport (event calendars, peak periods)
*   risk owners: brand, safety, compliance, reputation

## Exercise

Choose one real offer (yours or a known sport-tech/fitness offer). Step 1: list every party who touches the deal from first contact to delivery. Step 2: assign each party a role label (payer, economic buyer, champion, user, technical evaluator, procurement, legal, finance). Step 3: write one sentence per role stating what they fear and what they want. Step 4: identify the single role that can stop the deal late and write the prevention action.

## Deliverable

One-page stakeholder matrix: columns = role, name or function, decision power (0 to 3), success metric, risk, required proof. Include a single paragraph: your primary champion plan and your primary blocker plan.

## Sources

*   [https://hbr.org/2015/03/making-the-consensus-sale](https://hbr.org/2015/03/making-the-consensus-sale)
*   [https://hbr.org/2012/07/the-end-of-solution-sales](https://hbr.org/2012/07/the-end-of-solution-sales)

lessons.title: Segment architecture: B2C vs B2B vs B2G
lessons.content:
# Segment architecture: B2C vs B2B vs B2G

**Objective:** Separate B2C, B2B, and B2G into independent go-to-market motions with distinct success metrics, constraints, and operating rhythms.

## Key concepts

*   B2C: adoption and retention economics
*   B2B: multi-stakeholder consensus and procurement
*   B2G: compliance-first and formal evaluation
*   success definitions by motion (leading and lagging indicators)
*   constraint mapping: legal, procurement, data, privacy

## Exercise

Create three motion cards. For each motion: define the buyer, the purchase trigger, the time-to-decision range, the primary proof required, and the first 3 KPIs to measure progress. Then write a one-paragraph definition of success that includes: target customer, measurable outcome, and an execution boundary (what you will not do).

## Deliverable

Three motion one-pagers. Each must include: ICP header, offer format, sales cycle range, top 3 objections, top 3 proof assets, top 3 KPIs with formulas.

## Sources

*   [https://www.salesforce.com/sales/pipeline/management/](https://www.salesforce.com/sales/pipeline/management/)
*   [https://www.salesforce.com/sales/pipeline/stages/](https://www.salesforce.com/sales/pipeline/stages/)

lessons.title: ICP and personas per motion
lessons.content:
# ICP and personas per motion

**Objective:** Build ICP portfolios that separate fit from hope, using explicit fit signals, disqualifiers, and measurable outcomes.

## Key concepts

*   firmographics and operational fit
*   fit signals versus nice-to-have signals
*   hard disqualifiers
*   outcome language and measurable impact
*   non-ICP list to protect focus

## Exercise

Create 6 ICP sheets (2 per motion). For each: write the job-to-be-done, 3 measurable outcomes, 5 fit signals, 5 disqualifiers, and the first proof you would show. Then write a short 'non-ICP' list: who you will not sell to and why.

## Deliverable

ICP pack (6 sheets) with a single scoring rule: Fit Score = (signals met) minus (disqualifiers triggered). Include a 'walk-away' rule that triggers disqualification.

## Sources

*   [https://meddicc.com/meddpicc-sales-methodology-and-process](https://meddicc.com/meddpicc-sales-methodology-and-process)
*   [https://www.huthwaiteinternational.com/spin-methodology](https://www.huthwaiteinternational.com/spin-methodology)

lessons.title: Offer packaging and pricing logic
lessons.content:
# Offer packaging and pricing logic

**Objective:** Package offers to match decision structures and risk profiles, using pilots, tiers, and governance-friendly terms.

## Key concepts

*   pilot versus rollout packaging
*   tiering and modular scope
*   service levels and acceptance criteria
*   risk controls: exit terms, data terms, brand safety
*   price logic tied to value and delivery cost

## Exercise

Build a packaging table with 3 B2B tiers, 2 B2C entry tiers, and 1 public-sector compliant bundle. For each package: list inclusions, exclusions, delivery responsibilities, SLA, success criteria, and an explicit upgrade path. Then write one paragraph: how pricing changes with scale.

## Deliverable

Packaging table plus inclusion rules. Include a 'pilot contract' skeleton section list: scope, success criteria, timeline, data handling, brand safety, reporting, exit clause.

## Sources

*   [https://hbr.org/2015/03/making-the-consensus-sale](https://hbr.org/2015/03/making-the-consensus-sale)
*   [https://hbr.org/2012/07/the-end-of-solution-sales](https://hbr.org/2012/07/the-end-of-solution-sales)

lessons.title: Proof system: outcomes, ROI, credibility
lessons.content:
# Proof system: outcomes, ROI, credibility

**Objective:** Build a proof system that reduces buyer risk by turning claims into measurable outcomes and credible evidence.

## Key concepts

*   outcome statements with baselines
*   measurement plans and attribution
*   case study structure (problem, intervention, result)
*   risk reversal: pilot hypotheses
*   credibility assets: references, third-party validation

## Exercise

Create one proof pack per motion. For each: write a measurable outcome statement with a baseline and a time window, define the data required to measure it, and list acceptable evidence types (screenshots, logs, third-party reports, invoices). Build a one-page case study outline.

## Deliverable

Proof pack outline: 3 case study shells + measurement plan. Include an evidence checklist that a buyer can audit.

## Sources

*   [https://hbr.org/2012/07/the-end-of-solution-sales](https://hbr.org/2012/07/the-end-of-solution-sales)
*   [https://meddicc.com/resources/the-science-of-sales-qualification](https://meddicc.com/resources/the-science-of-sales-qualification)

lessons.title: Direct vs indirect decision framework
lessons.content:
# Direct vs indirect decision framework

**Objective:** Decide which segments must be sold direct versus partner-led, based on margin, control, conflict risk, and enablement cost.

## Key concepts

*   partner economics (margin and enablement cost)
*   channel conflict and deal protection
*   co-sell versus referral versus resale
*   control versus scale trade-offs
*   partner fit and capability gating

## Exercise

Take 10 target accounts and classify each: direct, partner-led, or co-sell. For each classification, write the reason in one sentence and list the minimum partner capability required (if partner-led). Define a conflict rule for when both direct and partner touch the account.

## Deliverable

Route-to-market decision matrix: account, route, reason, required proof, owner, conflict rule.

## Sources

*   [https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/partner-center/enroll/csp-overview](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/partner-center/enroll/csp-overview)
*   [https://help.salesforce.com/s/articleView?id=experience.networks\_leaddist\_dealreg.htm&language=en\_US&type=5](https://help.salesforce.com/s/articleView?id=experience.networks_leaddist_dealreg.htm&language=en_US&type=5)

options: To make performance repeatable through skills, process, and assets

quizQuestions.question: Why should enablement differ across distinct sales motions?
options: It should not differ; one playbook fits all
Different buyers require different stages, proof, and compliance requirements

quizQuestions.question: What should certification validate first?
options: Ability to run the process: qualify, discover, propose, and govern correctly

quizQuestions.question: Which asset is most critical for new reps to avoid low-quality pipeline?
What is the strongest indicator enablement is working?
options: Improved stage conversion and higher deal quality with consistent execution
More meetings booked regardless of fit

quizQuestions.question: Which is the most common failure mode in enablement?
options: Content without practice, coaching, and enforcement of standards

quizQuestions.question: What is the most defensible approach to keeping enablement current?
options: Run a feedback loop from win-loss, objections, and delivery issues into the playbook
Let partners update it ad hoc
Avoid changes to keep it stable

quizQuestions.question: What is the primary purpose of revenue operations alignment?
options: To add more tools to the stack
To ensure marketing, sales, partners, and delivery execute as one system
To eliminate the need for qualification

quizQuestions.question: Which handoff is most critical to prevent churn in complex deals?
options: Sales to delivery/customer success with documented success criteria

quizQuestions.question: What is the strongest indicator that a handoff process is broken?
options: The implementation team receives unclear scope and undefined success metrics
The CRM has too many fields
The team uses different meeting tools

quizQuestions.question: Which practice most improves forecast reliability in a multi-channel setup?
options: Standard stage evidence and shared definitions across direct and partner deals
Allowing each team to define stages independently

quizQuestions.question: What is the most defensible way to manage partner-sourced opportunities in CRM?
options: Track them outside CRM to reduce clutter
Use consistent attribution rules and enforce required fields and evidence
Credit whoever claims the deal first

quizQuestions.question: What should be documented before a deal is allowed to move to “commit”?
options: Decision process, stakeholders, success criteria, and close plan

quizQuestions.question: Which output most increases cross-functional accountability?
options: An action log with owner, deadline, and definition of done

# Revenue operations alignment

**Objective:** Align marketing, sales, partners, and delivery through handoffs, shared definitions, and enforceable governance.

## Key concepts

*   handoff quality
*   shared definitions
*   attribution and ownership
*   forecast alignment
*   operating system documentation

## Exercise

Define the handoff from sales to delivery: required fields, success criteria, scope, risks, and owners. Define partner-sourced opportunity rules for attribution and evidence.

## Deliverable

Revenue ops alignment plan plus process map and a handoff checklist.

## Sources

# Launch readiness for 90-day rollout

**Objective:** Create a launch readiness system with gates, owners, and measurable early indicators.

## Key concepts

*   launch gates
*   cross-functional owners
*   communications
*   early KPI selection
*   assumption tracking

## Exercise

Build a launch checklist across all motions. Define: gate conditions, owners, and required assets. Define the first 4-week KPI set and review actions.

## Deliverable

90-day launch checklist plus communications plan and assumptions register.

## Sources

*   [https://hbr.org/2015/03/making-the-consensus-sale](https://hbr.org/2015/03/making-the-consensus-sale)

quizQuestions.question: What does “launch readiness” primarily mean in go-to-market execution?
options: People, process, assets, and measurement are ready to run consistently

quizQuestions.question: Which is the most common cause of a failed go-to-market rollout?
options: Launching without clear owners, gates, and operating cadence

quizQuestions.question: What is a “gate” in a rollout plan?
options: A condition that must be met before progressing to the next phase

quizQuestions.question: Which checklist item most directly prevents pipeline pollution at launch?
options: ICP and disqualifiers documented and enforced

quizQuestions.question: Why should communication planning be part of launch readiness?
options: It aligns expectations across teams and prevents confusion in execution

quizQuestions.question: Which metric is most useful in the first 2 to 4 weeks of rollout?
options: Stage conversion and qualified pipeline creation

quizQuestions.question: What is the most defensible response when early rollout data contradicts assumptions?
options: Update assumptions, adjust tactics, and document changes with evidence
Change the product immediately without analysis

lessons.content:
# KPI dashboards and reporting

**Objective:** Define KPI formulas, reporting cadence, and review actions so metrics drive decisions, not decoration.

## Key concepts

*   leading vs lagging indicators
*   KPI formulas
*   auditability
*   metric gaming prevention
*   reporting cadence

## Exercise

Define KPIs per motion with formulas and owners. Define a weekly reporting calendar and the decision actions triggered by each KPI.

## Deliverable

KPI deck outline plus reporting calendar and KPI definition dictionary.

## Sources

*   [https://www.salesforce.com/sales/pipeline/management/](https://www.salesforce.com/sales/pipeline/management/)

quizQuestions.question: What is the primary job of a KPI dashboard in a sales system?
options: To display as many numbers as possible
To enable decisions by showing leading and lagging indicators tied to outcomes

quizQuestions.question: What is the difference between leading and lagging indicators?
options: Leading indicators predict outcomes; lagging indicators confirm outcomes
Lagging indicators are more accurate in real time
Leading indicators are always vanity metrics

quizQuestions.question: Which KPI is most likely to be a leading indicator of future revenue?
What is the biggest risk of tracking too many KPIs?
options: Loss of focus and conflicting behaviours

quizQuestions.question: Which principle best prevents metric gaming?
options: Define metrics with clear formulas, ownership, and auditability

quizQuestions.question: Which view is most useful for diagnosing a pipeline problem?
What should trigger a KPI redesign?
options: Metrics no longer correlate with outcomes or drive the right behaviour
The team asks for fewer reports

lessons.title: Risk and escalation playbooks
lessons.content:
# Risk and escalation playbooks

**Objective:** Identify predictable risks (deal, partner, procurement, delivery) and create escalation playbooks with owners and timelines.

## Key concepts

*   risk triggers
*   mutual plan gaps
*   partner conflict
*   procurement delays
*   post-signature churn prevention

## Exercise

Define the top 10 risks and write: trigger, impact, mitigation, escalation owner, and time box. Include a post-signature risk checklist.

## Deliverable

Risk playbook plus escalation map and a post-signature success protection checklist.

## Sources

*   [https://hbr.org/2015/03/making-the-consensus-sale](https://hbr.org/2015/03/making-the-consensus-sale)
*   [https://www.acquisition.gov/browse/index/far](https://www.acquisition.gov/browse/index/far)

quizQuestions.question: What is the purpose of an escalation playbook in sales execution?
options: To handle predictable risks with clear actions, owners, and timelines

quizQuestions.question: Which is the strongest early warning sign of deal risk?
options: The buyer asks for implementation details
No confirmed decision process or next step with owner and date
The buyer requests a case study
The buyer adds stakeholders to a call

quizQuestions.question: What is the most common root cause of late-stage deal failure?
options: Unresolved risks around scope, value proof, or procurement steps

quizQuestions.question: Which channel risk requires a predefined escalation path?
options: Deal ownership disputes between direct and partner routes

quizQuestions.question: What is the most defensible mitigation for procurement delays?
options: Build a mutual plan with documented steps, deadlines, and required documents

quizQuestions.question: Which risk is most likely to create churn after signature?
options: The buyer negotiated a small discount
Success criteria and responsibilities were not documented before handoff
The buyer requested a faster kickoff

quizQuestions.question: What should happen after an escalation resolves?
options: Document the root cause and update the playbook to prevent recurrence

lessons.content:
# Final blueprint and 90-day operating plan

**Objective:** Synthesize the system into a single operating plan that can be executed, measured, and improved.

## Key concepts

*   owners and accountability
*   gates and cadence
*   KPI operating rhythm
*   partner governance
*   procurement readiness integration

## Exercise

Assemble the final blueprint: motions, ICPs, packages, channels, pipeline, partners, procurement readiness, KPIs, and risks. Produce a 90-day plan with weekly milestones.

## Deliverable

Complete blueprint plus 90-day operating cadence: weekly agenda, scorecards, review actions, and change log rules.

quizQuestions.question: What makes a go-to-market plan “operational” rather than aspirational?
options: It includes owners, timelines, targets, and a cadence for inspection and adjustment

quizQuestions.question: What is the most important component of a 90-day execution plan?
options: Weekly milestones tied to measurable outcomes and accountability
A list of possible future features

quizQuestions.question: Which deliverable best proves a sales system is ready for handover?
options: Documented playbooks, governance rules, KPI definitions, and operating cadence

quizQuestions.question: What is the most defensible way to test whether the operating system works?
options: Assume it works if the team likes it
Run a short cycle, inspect data and quality, then iterate based on evidence
Wait until the end of the quarter

quizQuestions.question: Which is the strongest sign that the plan is overcomplicated?
options: It cannot be executed with current resources and owners cannot explain priorities

quizQuestions.question: What should a final measurement plan include at minimum?
options: KPI definitions, reporting cadence, data owners, and review actions

quizQuestions.question: What is the most defensible approach to continuous improvement after rollout begins?
options: Use structured reviews to update playbooks and assumptions based on results
